Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Sniffing Position and Simple Head Extension for Laryngoscopic Intubation

Trial_Design.evidence: randomised into two groups: SP (n=250) and simple head extension (n=250)

Participants.evidence: 500 adult patients (ASA Physical Status I–III) scheduled for elective surgery under general anesthesia

Intervention.evidence: randomised into two groups: SP (n=250) and simple head extension (n=250)

Objective.evidence: This study compares the sniffing position (SP) with simple head extension to evaluate laryngoscopic view and intubation difficulty.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the Intubation Difficulty Scale (IDS) score, measured during intubation.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: The anesthesiologist performing the intubation was not blinded.

Number_Randomised.evidence: randomised into two groups: SP (n=250) and simple head extension (n=250)

Result_Outcome.evidence: The IDS score was significantly lower in the SP group compared to the simple head extension group (p=0.000)
